p: Elshafie et al. (2015) [ 17] evaluated the antifungal effect of the single components of O. vulgare EO (carvacrol, thymol, linalool, and trans-caryophyllene) against the postharvest pathogens M. laxa, M. fructigena, and M. fructicola ( Figure 2). The fungicidal activity assay of the above four single components has been carried out in vitro according to the method of Soylu et al. (2010) [ 21] and the antifungal activity was expressed by measuring the diameter of mycelium growth [ 82]. They concluded that carvacrol and thymol have exhibited the highest activity in in vitro tests against all studied postharvest Monilinia pathogens. Linalool and trans-caryophyllene showed low antifungal activity against all studied pathogens. However, thymol showed a fungitoxic effect while carvacrol and citral showed a fungistatic effect against the previous tested fungi.
